How to organise your finances

You are viewing a page of the Starting a Business Guide

How to organise your finances

Last Updated: 20 September 2019

When starting a business, there are things you'll need to consider to organise your finances, such as bookkeeping, payments and your budget. Follow our steps to organise your finances and keep your business on track.

    On this page
  • 1. Set up a business bank account
  • 2. Set up a bookkeeping system
  • 3. Prepare a budget
  • 4. Payment types and invoicing templates
  • 5. Manage your cash flow

1. Set up a business bank account

If you operate as a sole trader you donâ€™t legally have to have a separate bank account for your business â€“ you can use your personal account. However, to easily track your business income and expenses, consider opening a separate business account.

If your business operates as a partnership, company or trust then you must have a separate business bank account for tax purposes.

Find out the benefits of setting up a business bank account.

Why set up a business bank account

Have a look at the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) Separate business and personal expenses information. Find out how to use a single bank account for both your personal and business finances.

Australian Taxation Office

Learn more about business structures.

Business structures

2. Set up a bookkeeping system

There are many manual and electronic bookkeeping products that could suit your business. If youâ€™ve employed a financial professional, have a chat to them about the products that will best work with their systems.

Learn why setting up a basic bookkeeping system helps you keep your books in order.

Record keeping

3. Prepare a budget

Preparing a budget outlining your forecast income and expenses helps you manage your cash flow when starting and running your business.

Find out how to create a budget for your business.

How to create a budget

4. Payment types and invoicing templates

You'll need to decide on your payment termsÂ and paymentÂ typesÂ your customers can use. You may also need to set up an invoicing template and receipts to give your customers when selling goods and services.

Itâ€™s important to provide a correct invoice for your goods and services. Make sure to include a clear due date and follow up on payments that fall behind. If your business provides subscriptions or memberships, consider setting up an automatic payment system or direct debit. This will save you the hassle of chasing payments.

Find out which payment terms and invoicing type you should use for your business.

Invoicing and payments explained

Learn how to create an invoicing template.

How to invoice

5. Manage your cash flow

Keep track of the money thatâ€™s coming in and going out of your business. An easy way to do this is to use a cash flow statement. A cash flow statement allows you to track your income and plan your expenses. This lets you plan ahead and feel comfortable in the knowledge that youâ€™ll have the money to pay your bills.

Learn how to set up your cash flow statement.

How to set up a cash flow statement
